## The Septuagint: A Greek Bible

The Septuagint is the oldest Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible. It was likely made by Jewish scholars in Alexandria, Egypt, around 250 BCE. The name comes from a story saying 72 translators worked on it.

Most Jews during this time spoke Greek or Aramaic, not Hebrew. So, the Septuagint made the Bible accessible to them.
